title: Bug 12906 [Editor Mgmt] Unable to open file in another editor if already opened in one editor (should give error message)
description: Bug 12906 [Editor Mgmt] If a file is already opened in one editor, it cannot be opened in another editor (should display an error message).
OB: When the file is opened in one editor, and the user tries to open the same file in another editor by right-clicking on it and selecting 'Open With... > System Editor', nothing happens. There should be a warning message displayed in the workbench, informing the user that opening the file may overwrite changes and asking for confirmation, or an error message stating that all files should be closed first. It is believed to be a safety feature where the IDE does not allow external editing while the file is already opened in the IDE.
EB: When the file is opened in one editor, and the user tries to open the same file in another editor by right-clicking on it and selecting 'Open With... > System Editor', a warning message should be displayed in the workbench. The warning message should inform the user that opening the file may overwrite changes and ask for confirmation, or display an error message stating that all files should be closed first. This is a safety feature to prevent external editing while the file is already opened in the IDE.
SR:
1. Ensure that there is an associated Windows editor for your java file. If not, go to the file explorer, double-click on any java file, and select WordPad or Notepad as the default editor for all java files.
2. In the Java Perspective, right-click on the java file and select 'Open With... > System Editor'.
3. A Notepad or Wordpad window should pop up with the java file opened. Close it.
4. Go to the Java Perspective and open a java file by double-clicking on it.
5. The file should now be opened in the workbench.
6. Right-click on the java file and select 'Open With... > System Editor'.
7. A warning message should be displayed in the workbench, informing you that opening the file may overwrite changes. It should give an option to continue with confirmation, or display an error message stating that all files should be closed first.
